messageBody:
To thousandshipz:

Welcome to the Read_Alphabet group. I just read your post on the
Shavian group. I found it interesting, especially the comment regarding
the Japanese using more than one alphabet. How relevant that is to
writing English, however, is another question. I do not know the
history behind the different Japanese writing systems -- when, why and
how they were developed. I assume it was a natural, evolutionary
process, and not an alternative design by one individual who was seeking
an improved writing system as Quikscript was.

I also appreciated your comment regarding QS. One of the reasons I
started the Read_Alphabet site was because I got so frustrated with the
Shavian group. They seem devoted to discussing minutae of the Shavian
alphabet ad infinitum: which pronunciation should we use, RP or NBC
English, what order should the alphabet letters be in, how should the
keyboard be mapped, should characters be allowed to have more than one
pronunciation to allow different dialects to share the same spelling,
etc.,etc.

When I first stumbled across Shavian, I wrote Kingsley Read in the early
to mid-seventies. He wrote back and sent me a copy of the QS manual.
He described QS as the improved version of Shavian. Naturally, once I
learned he revised the Shavian alphabet in ways which he felt made it
better, it made sense to me to shift to QS from Shavian. The thought of
continuing to use Shavian, when its author had abandoned it, never
occurred to me.

That is why I have found it so difficult to understand the philosophy
driving the Shavian group. Most of them, perhaps all, know that QS
exists, but they prefer to continue using the Beta model of the
alphabet. When I questioned this position, the answer given was that
the publication of Androcles and the Lion in Shavian had made so many
more people aware of Shavian in comparison to QS that they continued to
foster its adoption rather than QS.

This is nonsensical to me. Out of several hundred million English
speakers, only a few thousand have even heard of Shavian and, probably
only a few hundred have tried writing it. This is, literally, the
proverbial drop in the bucket. It is not as if we have a big ground
swell of people already favoring Shavian.

Most adults use the curvise roman alphabet when they write by hand. QS
has a more cursive appearance than Shavian and avoids its mandatory
pen-lifts between every letter. In other words, it is more similar in
those two characteristics to the roman alphabet than Shavian is. The
pen-lifts make Shavian slower to write than QS and the letters,
especially the diphthongs, are more difficult to write correctly.
Despite Quikscript's initial unfamiliarity, I believe the features it
has in common with the roman alphabet would give it an advantage for its
adoption as an alternative alphabet in comparison to Shavian. In
addition, the use of the half-letters, which do not exist in Shavian,
gives QS words more distinctive shapes, which, due to faster recognition
times, should lead to higher reading speeds in comparison to Shavian.
And before anyone objects to the use of half-letters in printed
material, the Jerome font, despite its limitations, has already shown
than computers can utilize the half-letters quite effectively so there
is no need for their use to be limited to handwriting.


Paige Gabhart
